COCO INFO-SHEET
COCo – The Centre for Community Organizations
3680 Jeanne-Mance, #470 Montreal (QC) H2X 2K5 ph: (514) 849-5599 or (866) 552-2626 fax: (514) 849-5553 or (866) 560-2626
info@coco-net.org | www.coco-net.org
 By-laws for Non Profit Organizations
What are by-laws anyway?
By-laws are the guiding rules that govern how we work as an organization. 
While the law creates an organization, the details of how the organization 
will function is left to us. We have to create the guidelines and rules that we 
want to follow, and those rules are called the by-laws. These by-laws must 
respect the limits that the law places on community organizations and the 
founding objectives laid out in the letters patent. 
These rules help to ensure that all members are treated fairly and give us a 
kind of roadmap about the way the organization works. For example, by-laws

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the importance of by-laws for non-profit organizations, explaining that by-laws are the guiding rules that govern how an organization operates. metadata.next_section_summary: The section discusses the importance of by-laws in ensuring fairness and providing a roadmap for how an organization operates. Key topics include defining membership, decision-making processes, transparency, and the role of by-laws in helping the board of directors fulfill the organization's mission. It emphasizes the need for clear, plain language in writing by-laws, avoiding ambiguity, using consistent terminology, defining key terms, and organizing the by-laws with titles and subtitles for user-friendliness. Gender-inclusive language is also recommended to ensure inclusivity.

metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How can by-laws help ensure fairness and transparency within a non-profit organization?
2. What key topics should be addressed in by-laws to provide a roadmap for decision-making and help the board of directors fulfill the organization's mission?
3. Why is it important for by-laws to be written in plain language and avoid ambiguity, according to the section on by-laws in the document?

__data__.text:
anyway?
By-laws are the guiding rules that govern how we work as an organization. 
While the law creates an organization, the details of how the organization 
will function is left to us. We have to create the guidelines and rules that we 
want to follow, and those rules are called the by-laws. These by-laws must 
respect the limits that the law places on community organizations and the 
founding objectives laid out in the letters patent. 
These rules help to ensure that all members are treated fairly and give us a 
kind of roadmap about the way the organization works. For example, by-laws 
should lay out who is considered to be a member of the organization and 
how decisions are made. Good by-laws help to prevent uncertainty and 
inconsistency and promote transparency. They provide an important 
framework for how the board of directors can help the organization to fulfill 
its mission. 
Healthy by-laws for a healthy organization
By-laws should be written in plain language and avoid jargon. Having clear 
wording is important to avoid ambiguity in what a given by-law was

1. How can by-laws help prevent uncertainty and inconsistency within an organization?
2. What are some key elements to consider when writing by-laws in order to promote transparency and inclusivity?
3. Why is it important to involve multiple people in the writing and reviewing process of by-laws, according to the provided context?

__data__.text:
that all members are treated fairly and give us a 
kind of roadmap about the way the organization works. For example, by-laws 
should lay out who is considered to be a member of the organization and 
how decisions are made. Good by-laws help to prevent uncertainty and 
inconsistency and promote transparency. They provide an important 
framework for how the board of directors can help the organization to fulfill 
its mission. 
Healthy by-laws for a healthy organization
By-laws should be written in plain language and avoid jargon. Having clear 
wording is important to avoid ambiguity in what a given by-law was meant to 
say. Keeping paragraphs short and sweet is important! Using the same key 
terms repeatedly throughout the by-laws can be important for clarity and 
consistency. It is also important to define key terms at the beginning of the 
by-laws. Organizing the by-laws with titles and subtitles can help to make 
them user-friendly. We can help to ensure that our by-laws don't leave 
people out by using gender-inclusive language (for example, using the

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the importance of by-laws in ensuring fairness and providing a roadmap for how an organization operates. It emphasizes the need for clear, plain language in writing by-laws, avoiding ambiguity, using consistent terminology, defining key terms, and organizing the by-laws with titles and subtitles for user-friendliness. Gender-inclusive language is also recommended to ensure inclusivity.

metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How can by-laws be written in plain language to avoid ambiguity and ensure clarity?
2. Why is it important to use gender-inclusive language in by-laws and involve multiple people in the writing and reviewing process?
3. What recommendations are provided for organizing by-laws with titles and subtitles to make them more user-friendly?

__data__.text:
should be written in plain language and avoid jargon. Having clear 
wording is important to avoid ambiguity in what a given by-law was meant to 
say. Keeping paragraphs short and sweet is important! Using the same key 
terms repeatedly throughout the by-laws can be important for clarity and 
consistency. It is also important to define key terms at the beginning of the 
by-laws. Organizing the by-laws with titles and subtitles can help to make 
them user-friendly. We can help to ensure that our by-laws don't leave 
people out by using gender-inclusive language (for example, using the plural 
pronoun they instead of the singular he or she). It is important to have 
multiple people involved in writing and reviewing the by-laws for clarity, 
coherence and to be sure they fit with the mandate.
PUBLISHED 2010

We can help to ensure that our by-laws don't leave

metadata.next_section_summary: This section discusses the importance of understanding and following by-laws within organizations to prevent misunderstandings and conflicts. It explains that by-laws are created when an organization is founded but may need to be modified as the organization grows and changes. It also outlines the process for making changes to by-laws or letters patent, including through Annual General Meetings (AGM) or Special General Meetings (SGM) where members can vote on proposed changes.
metadata.section_summary: This section discusses the importance of by-laws for organizations, particularly in terms of board member liability. It provides links to sample by-laws for voluntary organizations and resources on board liability for non-profit organizations. The section emphasizes the need for by-laws to be understood and followed by all members of the organization to prevent misunderstandings and conflicts. It also mentions that by-laws are typically created when an organization is founded but may need to be revised as the organization grows.

Making by-laws meaningful
Having good by-laws on paper is important, but ensuring that people know 
what the by-laws are, where they are kept, and what they mean in the daily 
working of our organizations takes some effort. Having a common 
interpretation of what the by-laws mean can help to prevent 
misunderstandings and conflicts as we work together for social change. It is 
important for staff and board members to have all read the by-laws, and 
have them guide the internal processes that we use. 
When are by-laws created?
The original by-laws are created when the organization is founded. However, 
as a group grows and

__data__.text:
is important, but ensuring that people know 
what the by-laws are, where they are kept, and what they mean in the daily

misunderstandings and conflicts as we work together for social change. It is 
important for staff and board members to have all read the by-laws, and 
have them guide the internal processes that we use. 
When are by-laws created?
The original by-laws are created when the organization is founded. However, 
as a group grows and changes, the by-laws may need to be modified too.
When do we make changes to the by-laws or our letters 
patent?
In Quebec, Annual General Meetings (AGM) and Special General Meetings 
(SGM) are the places where proposed constitutional or by-law changes 
prepared by the board of directors can be accepted or rejected by a vote of 
the members attending the a general meeting. If there is no AGM coming up, 
we can call a SGM to

metadata.next_section_summary: The section discusses the approval process for changes to by-laws and letters patent within a non-profit organization. It highlights that changes to by-laws require a simple majority of the assembly, while changes to letters patent require a 2/3 vote at a general assembly. The membership has the power to accept or reject proposed changes by the board but cannot modify them. The section also provides a link to a COCo infosheet on Annual General Meetings, Special General Meetings, and Non-Profit Organizations for more information.

metadata.next_section_summary: This section discusses the importance of by-laws in non-profit organizations and the process for making changes to them. It highlights that changes to the letters patent must be approved by a 2/3 vote at a general assembly, and that the membership has the power to accept or reject proposed changes by the board. The section also provides resources for more information on AGMs, SGMs, and by-laws, including a COCo infosheet and a guide by Paul Martel on the rights, duties, and responsibilities of non-profit organization administrators.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the approval process for changes to by-laws and letters patent within a non-profit organization. It highlights that changes to by-laws require a simple majority of the assembly, while changes to letters patent require a 2/3 vote at a general assembly. The membership has the power to accept or reject proposed changes by the board but cannot modify them. The section also provides a link to a COCo infosheet on Annual General Meetings, Special General Meetings, and Non-Profit Organizations for more information.

It highlights that changes to the letters patent must be approved by a 2/3 vote at a general assembly, and that the membership has the power to accept or reject proposed changes by the board. The section also provides resources for more information on AGMs, SGMs, and by-laws, including a COCo infosheet and a guide by Paul Martel on the rights, duties, and responsibilities of non-profit organization administrators.
metadata.next_section_summary: This section discusses the importance of democratic governance in non-profit organizations (NPOs) and provides a toolbox for implementing democratic governance practices. It also includes contact information for COCo (Centre for Community Organizations) for assistance and emphasizes that the information provided is general and not legal advice. The section encourages consulting a lawyer for professional assurance and offers a list of lawyers with experience working with community groups.

metadata.next_section_summary: The section discusses the importance of by-laws in governing how an organization functions. By-laws are rules that must respect legal limits and founding objectives, ensuring fairness and providing a roadmap for decision-making. Good by-laws prevent uncertainty and promote transparency, guiding the board of directors in fulfilling the organization's mission. It is recommended that by-laws be written in plain language to avoid ambiguity.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the importance of by-laws for non-profit organizations, explaining that by-laws are the guiding rules that govern how an organization operates. By-laws must respect legal limits and founding objectives, and help ensure fair treatment of all members. They provide a roadmap for how the organization functions.
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How can by-laws help ensure fair treatment of all members within a non-profit organization?
2. What role do by-laws play in providing a roadmap for decision-making within an organization?
3. Why is it important for by-laws to be written in plain language to avoid ambiguity?

metadata.prev_section_summary: This section discusses the importance of using gender-inclusive language in by-laws to ensure inclusivity. It also emphasizes the need for multiple people to be involved in writing and reviewing by-laws for clarity and coherence. The section also states that the information provided is general and not legal advice, and recommends consulting a lawyer for professional assurance. The section is published by COCo in 2010.
metadata.next_section_summary: This section discusses the importance of by-laws for organizations, particularly in terms of board member liability. It provides links to sample by-laws for voluntary organizations and resources on board liability for non-profit organizations. The section emphasizes the need for by-laws to be understood and followed by all members of the organization to prevent misunderstandings and conflicts. It also mentions that by-laws are typically created when an organization is founded but may need to be revised as the organization grows.
metadata.section_summary: This section discusses the importance of including a by-law that limits the liability of board members in case of legal action against the organization. It provides links to sample by-laws for voluntary organizations and an infosheet on board liability and non-profit organizations. The section emphasizes the importance of not only having good by-laws on paper but also ensuring that people are aware of them, know where they are kept, and understand their implications in daily operations.
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How can organizations limit the liability of board members in case of legal action?
2. Where can organizations find sample by-laws on board member liability for voluntary organizations?
3. Why is it important for organizations to ensure that people are aware of their by-laws, know where they are kept, and understand their implications in daily operations?

metadata.prev_section_summary: This section discusses the process of making changes to bylaws, including the need for a vote of the members at a general meeting or a special general meeting (SGM) if an AGM is not scheduled. It also emphasizes that the information provided is general in nature and recommends consulting a lawyer for professional advice tailored to specific situations. The section also mentions that COCo does not provide legal advice and cannot take responsibility for the interpretation of the information in their info-sheets.
metadata.next_section_summary: This section discusses the importance of by-laws in non-profit organizations and the process for making changes to them. It highlights that changes to the letters patent must be approved by a 2/3 vote at a general assembly, and that the membership has the power to accept or reject proposed changes by the board. The section also provides resources for more information on AGMs, SGMs, and by-laws, including a COCo infosheet and a guide by Paul Martel on the rights, duties, and responsibilities of non-profit organization administrators.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the approval process for changes to by-laws and letters patent within a non-profit organization. It highlights that changes to by-laws require a simple majority of the assembly, while changes to letters patent require a 2/3 vote at a general assembly. The membership has the power to accept or reject proposed changes by the board but cannot modify them. The section also provides a link to a COCo infosheet on Annual General Meetings, Special General Meetings, and Non-Profit Organizations for more information.
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. What is the process for making changes to bylaws and letters patent within a non-profit organization?
2. What is the voting requirement for approving changes to bylaws and letters patent at a general assembly?
3. What resources are available for more information on Annual General Meetings, Special General Meetings, and Non-Profit Organizations, as well as by-laws in general?
